name: Fame Free Podcast
summary: A special podcast that was made available as a giveaway to people that went to see Gervais' standup tour Fame.

transcript.content: Hi, welcome to the Ricky, Gervais show with me Ricky Gervais, Stephen Merchant.
Hello there.
And the Shaving monkey with a head like a fucking orange, that is Karl Pilkington.
All right.
Well, this is a special edition. A free giveaway podcast, that people who came to see my show Fame in London got, put on their seat, gratis. Thanks for coming.

Well, unless you didn't even come, and still got this free. Unless someone went: "I didn't want. It was rubbish" and gave it to you, you're listening to it for free. Or you've sort of downloaded it illegally. It was free anyway! Ah, forget it.
We've been away for a while now. We're back together.
The old team.
The old team back together in a little room in central London.
Karl? Looking back on the year, what's happened? I remember last year the most memorable thing that happened was, you saw a grubby in a biscuit so...
That was a highlight that into his diary.
Yeah. So what's the big thing of this year? What's the big thing so far of 2007 that, as if I say 2007, you'll go: "Oh, yeah, that was the year that..."
In years to come?
Yeah, in 10 years time
Yeah, I'll go remember 2007? You go "Of course I do. It was the year that..."
I'm haven't really been following what's going on cause of all our other light personal issues
Well yeah, what's the big...?
It's me boiler... It's me boiler is playing up still. Sick of it.
Your what?
Me boiler. ,
The boiler?
The boiler, that heats the water up and stuff. Except it doesn't.
You know what I'd do in that situation? I'd instantly get a repairman out to sort it out.
Done that, done that twice. It was 80 quid for him just to say, looks like you need a new one.
Why didn't you get a new one then?
Because you then you wondered, you meant to believe him, or is he out to sort of trying to con me.
Well he's the expert.
Yeah but is he?
Well I don't know.
It's like you have to get a second opinion.
So that was the first time then, so what was the second time? Who came out the second time?
It was the same fella
And what did he say? Why did you call me?
I thought you were gonna get a second opinion.
I know, but I called the company and they just sent him again, because I think
Well call a different company!
What was it? What was his second opinion? For 80 quid.
That he under charged you and it's now 150?
No, because they said they must look in the book and sort of go: "Oh, you know, Harry went round there" or whatever. And and they must think what he went there last time so he knows situation.
Yeah.
And got the same fella again, so he turned up
Well, then you got the same opinion I assume
Same answer, yeah
Okay, yeah so two twice you've called someone out and they said you need a new boiler. He had the overalls on, holding a monkey wrench again. He came in a van.
Yeah
He charged you. He's the professional. Why haven't you got a new boiler?
Because then he went on to say that you know, it's a dangerous set up I've got. It shouldn't be set up the way it is, it's dangerous. Something about gas leaking out of it.
Silent laugh from Ricky
He said you know, "you don't sleep close to this do you?" And I said "well bedroom's there" it's not a big flat, you've seen it Steve.
Yeah.
Ricky laughs
Everything's en suite innit?
(laughing) "Everything's en suite"! Oh dear
So yeah anyway. He just sort of said look, you know, he doesn't want to touch it. He said you need to get someone in who can sort this out for you but
What? And it took him two visits and 160 to feel that out?
Yeah, this is what they do init?
So what's his advice?
He just said, you know, there are people out there who will touch it, if you pay the right money.
Well, okay, so you're going to get an expert in who does this thing, and sorts it out so -
Well, No. I called me dad -
Oh yeah.
Oh yeah.

'Cause he always knows someone who's can sort stuff out, and he said, "Oh, one of your cousins is a, is a boiler man. And yeah, they're coming around, but I've never met him and it turns out that - that person, because like, the whole family, you know, I'm not into sort of keeping in touch with people-
Sure.

I haven't spoke to me brother for, like, I don't know, 12 years and sister about 15 years and that. So, the idea of this cousin, who I've... I mean he might as well not have said he's me cousin, because because I'm not going to know him anyway. I mean, that last fellow Harry might as well 'ave been related. So they're gonna turn up, and now it turns out that, because I haven't seen the rest of the family, they're going to, like, use this as a reunion.
Ugh...
What, so they're all going to come round, whilst -
They're all coming round.
- whilst he fixes the boiler?
Yeah, and I hate it, I hate family things anyway.
So they're going to come around and just look at you?

Well, yeah, apart from the one who's fixing it, he'll be fixing it, and the others will just be sat around sort of going, "So how've you be been?" It's like, well where do you start? I haven't seen - seriously - I mean, they are strangers. When they buzz, I could be letting anyone in. When they buzz the door...
And so you're going to entertain them all in your flat, tiny little flat?
Well, I said to me dad I might just say that I've got to go to a meeting, let them in, and then shoot off.
I love that. So now, they're strangers that you're letting in your flat and you're not even being there. That's that's the best thing, that's, that's security.

Now, Karl says he'll remember this year for his boiler, um, being a bit of a pain. But now, everyone knows, over the past sort of like few years, my big pet project hasn't been my own career, it's been; Get Karl Famous.
Yeah
I want people to recognize him in the street, come up to him, and say, "You bald-headed Manc twat" Make his life, I want -
Well, let me tell you now, Rick
Go on.
I've been out and about and a lot people have said to me, they've come at me and said, "Has Karl Pilkington got a head like a fucking orange?" I've had to instantly confirm the answer to be, yes.

Well, I'm in America quite a bit and it doesn't matter whether I'm talking to David Bowie, The Simpsons, all these people, people on 24, all these people who have got these amazing careers and lives, say, "Is Karl Pilkington really like that? I say, "Yes, he's not two short planks, he's three or four fucking short, fucking planks-
Thick but short planks.
Fucking lumps of thickness.

- but, he's at a call. He had a call recently from a film company, asking him if he's got any ideas for movies. Now, how desperate, how, in what dire straits must the British film industry be, that they're going -
They're turning to Karl Pilkington -

I went, I went along and I had a meeting, in a cafe

Because you can provide any of that.

So thought of this idea, sort of on the spot. Good, always how I am not but sometimes that's how good ideas come up. Yeah.
Yeah a lot of yours have
Yeah. No. But when if you just talk I find that your mouth comes out with stuff, right?

There's another quote, right. There's another quote that if you talk, that comes out words that I've got that that to me is stands along with what were those things in Gremlins called, does your brain rule you or do you rule your brain?

No, but I mean if you sit there and try and use your brain to do it, right, it doesn't work the same, just just keep talking, just keep you keep your mouth talking and eventually it will come out with something pretty good.

That is exactly what Plato said. So, so Aristotle, we said, sit down. I've got an idea for you Aristotle said playing card. What you got, right? Just keep talking. And eventually, your brain will come out with stuff.

So what I thought, I just started off by saying, like actors names and that we thought should be in it because then that's giving giving more of this building, right? So I said, right, I'm seeing Clive. Warren

They're going out and together and that yeah
Clive Warren and Rebecca Demornay.
I said, it's one of them where starts off.

Think about this Rick, as a description of a holiday.
Right, okay. Okay.
Ok, you- as Karl said he loves to go travelling, it broadens the mind.
Yeah.
This is what he did, he's there with his family, he's in Madeira.
I didn't do much this morning, just sat by the pool, saving insects that flew into it.
Ricky explodes with laughter
I'm gonna die! Like fucking Noah! That's amazing! Nothing... like...
How were you
Saving them? Did you wait for them to hit the water then fish them out? Or you grab them in the air?
Oh!
I'd just see their legs going.
Ricky laughs
Oh god!
Stuck me finger on the top, they grabbed on, lifted it off.
And what, when it like, some sort of insect lifeguard, you'd see summat landing then you'd go, "Right, that's me!"
Ricky hums Superman theme
And you'd go in there?

But it's hard to turn a, sort of, a blind eye to stuff like that, because, you know, that something, you know, you're witnessing death. And if you can save something, you do, don't you? You do your bit. And at night, I'd sort of think, have they learnt their lesson or will they be back? And will they be dead in here tomorrow? But if they can get an extra day,
I've done me bit. I can't do more than that. I am on holiday, do your bit.
Steve laughs
I'm lucky enough to see the world. Do your bit.
Ricky laughs
I love it.
I did me bit.
I love it. I love it. I love the fact that he was running around saving flies and things.
It's just something - there's something so, sort of-
Meanwhile, an old lady drowned.
Steve laughs
Yeah.
While he was saving a beetle.
There's something so, kind of, I don't know... desperately existential about your diary.
Ricky laughs
Yeah.
That's what's so extraordinary about it.
Yeah.
As he says, I just sat by the pool, saving insects that flew into it. It was full of death.
Ricky laughs
Oh god.
It's just so - it's so depressing, it's so-
Alright.
We walked around the shops. Suzanne's dad bought two packets of the biscuits he liked to take back home with him. Suzanne's mam bought a tin of corned beef. Was a bit of a boring day today.
Jesus.
There was a dead bird out the back. Oh f-
Oh no! Where were you, Karl?
Steve laughs
Suzanne's dad said it looked like it had flown into a wall and killed itself.
No, I think it'd caught a few insects but they were covered in chlorine, so it
Poisoned it.
Loads of ants were eating it.
Oh god.
I dug a hole under a tree and buried it. The ants were still all hanging around the scene of the death ages after the burial.
Suzanne's dad said I should have left the bird for the ants to eat because I was messing up the food chain. I felt bad so I gave the ants some breadcrumbs.
This is weird.
This is just so dark.
This is really weird.
It's good bread out there though, innit. I should have put that.
We have to eat all the food we've got because we're going home tomorrow. Suzanne's mam cut her finger opening the corned beef tin and fainted.
Ricky laughs
Sorry! This is really weird. Why'd you have to eat all the food?
He's in this, like, what was it? What's that film? The, uh, Amityville Horror
Where there's  like a haunted house and there's dead insects and ghostly children walking through the corridors. Old people fainting.
No, but-
Insects. "I'm just saving the insects, Mother."
But you always eat all the food that's, that's in the fridge before you go home. Don't you? It's all there to be eaten. And she bought some pikelets. Which I-
What?
-I'd never had em. They're like squashed crumpets.
Right, okay. Start again. Start that whole thing again. She bought some what?
Some pikelets.
Pikelets?
Yeah.
Yeah.
And I didn't like them because they're not as fat as crumpets.
Ricky laughs
Oh god! I just - it's like a different language!
The, the
And it was a big upheaval because, like, I was going home and her Dad kept trying to sneak them into our bags. Because it's like, "They were for you, you take them - "
Smuggling!

"We don't want your stuff in our house!" Because he gets a bit funny about stuff being left over. There's bins that you can't put certain stuff in. There's a bin in the lounge and I put a Tangerine peel in, and he goes "That sort of stuff does not go in that bin". I said, 'It's Rubbish,' "Yeah but it's not the right sort of rubbish."
But -
Someone will camp next to it.
*Laughs*
Yeah! We want to get a better class of camper. Oh, that's the book, and it's called 'Happy slapped by a Jellyfish'.
Yeah, that's from one of the chapters in it.
By Karl Pilkington. Get that soon.
Particularly if you're thinking of visiting, uh, Madeira or Australia.

Yeah, well, that's about it. Thanks for listening to this. If you've enjoyed this and you haven't heard the others, we've got the whole, um, all three series on iTunes. You can go and download those. Uh -
'The Ricky Gervais Show', is that what it's called?

It's called 'The Ricky Gervais Show', yeah. Um. Karl's also made a programme for me, Steve. On my 'Fame' DVD, out in November. It's called 'Fame', so, I thought of a little title: "Fame - I'm going to live forever". Remember that guy we met, who's gonna live forever?
Oh yeah.
Called Howard. That was a meeting of minds. And, it's um, it's Karl meeting Howard.
Good little holiday.

It's really good, isn't it? It's really good. And they do - he really gets on with him. And we're probably going to do a new series of the podcast maybe next year. What do you think, Karl? If you're not too busy making this film with Clive Warren.
Uh, we'll see how it goes. Don't plan anything.
Yeah, just check out RickyGervais.com. I am Ricky Gervais, with me - Stephen Merchant.
Goodbye.
And Karl.
Alright.

synopsis.description: Karl's holiday is so boring a bird commits suicide
Karl's holiday continues with more fascinating food-related anecdotes, including the infamous pikelets
